org.latency4j

Class WorkDuration

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.latency4j.WorkDuration
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class WorkDuration
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable

    Encapsulates the duration of an operation, task or unit of work. A monitor returns an instance of this class for each completion of a unit of monitored work.

    See Also:
    LatencyMonitor.taskCompleted(), Serialized Form

    • Constructor Summary

    • Constructor Detail

      • WorkDuration

        public WorkDuration(WorkDurationId identifier,
                    java.lang.String methodName,
                    long start,
                    long end,
                    boolean root,
                    boolean errored)

        Public constructor.

        Parameters:
        identifier - The duration's identifier (primary key). This simplifies persistence and loading.
        methodName - The method in which the monitor, which produced this duration, was triggered.
        start - The start time of the task, represented as a timestamp, to which the new instance relates.
        end - The end time of the task, represented as a timestamp, to which the new instance relates.
        root - Denotes if the new instance corresponds to the root of the method calls comprising the call stack over which the executed operation spans.
        errored - A value of true denotes that the task ended with an exception, and a value of false otherwise.

    • Method Detail

      • start

        public static WorkDuration start(java.lang.String workCategory,
                                 java.lang.String methodName)

        Indicates the start of a category of work or task. If this instance relates to a specific requirement, the category would match that specified in the requirement.

        Parameters:
        workCategory - The identifier for the category of work being started.
        methodName - The name of the method within which this call is made. In the case of proxied and intercepted method calls, this would be the name of the target method whose call was intercepted.
        Returns:
        An instance encapsulating the specified information, as well as thread and timing information.

      • isRoot

        public boolean isRoot()

        Indicates if the method is the root of the call stack relating to the work being monitored.

        Returns:
        True if this duration relates to the root method in the call stack representing the work being monitored, and False otherwise. setRoot(boolean)

      • setRoot

        public void setRoot(boolean root)

        Specified if the method, to which the instance is associated, is the root of the call stack relating to the work being monitored.

        Parameters:
        root - A value of True if this duration was initiated from the root method in the call stack representing the work being monitored, and False otherwise. setRoot(boolean)

      • isErrored

        public boolean isErrored()

        Indicates if the work being monitored ended prematurely with an exception.

        Returns:
        True If an exception occurred within the monitored block of the method, and False otherwise.

      • setErrored

        public void setErrored(boolean errored)

        Sets the internal flag which indicates that the task, to which the duration relates, terminated with an exception.

        Parameters:
        errored - A value of True indicates that an error occurred, and False indicates otherwise.

      • getError

        public java.lang.Throwable getError()

        In the case where a task terminates with an exception, and the call isErrored() returns True, this method should return a reference to the exception object.

        Returns:
        The exception which caused the task being monitored to fail.
        See Also:
        isErrored()

      • setError

        public void setError(java.lang.Throwable error)

        This method should only be called to specify the details of an error which caused the termination of the task being monitored. It should not be invoked directly by clients, as it is almost certain that any such invocation will be ignored in the best case, and, in the worst case, cause indeterminate behaviour in the Latency4J runtime.

        Parameters:
        error - A reference to the exception object.

      • getIdentifier

        public WorkDurationId getIdentifier()

        Returns the identifier/primary-key of the instance.

        Returns:
        The instance's key.

      • getMethodName

        public java.lang.String getMethodName()

        The name of the method from which the task segment being monitored was initiated.

        Returns:
        The name of the method from which the duration originates.

      • markFinished

        public void markFinished()

        Sets the completion time (end) time of the duration to the current system time. This is essentially a marker method which specifies the end-time of the task to which the duration relates.

        See Also:
        getEndTime(), getElapsedTime()

      • getElapsedTime

        public long getElapsedTime()

        Returns the total elapsed time of the monitored task in milliseconds. This is equivalent to the statement endTime -startTime.

        Returns:
        The total milliseconds elapsed between the end and start of the task being monitored.

      • getStartTime

        public long getStartTime()

        Returns the start time of the monitored task. This is equivalent to the point at which the method LatencyMonitor.taskStarted() is invoked.

        Returns:
        The time (in milliseconds) at which the monitored task started.

      • getEndTime

        public long getEndTime()

        This is equivalent to the point in time at which either the method LatencyMonitor.taskCompleted() or LatencyMonitor.taskErrored(Throwable) is invoked.

        Returns:
        The time (in milliseconds) the monitored task was completed.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object candidate)

        Override of the equals method. Two duration instances are considered equal if all of their fields are equivalent. For the purposes of comparison null values for the error field are treated as equivalent.

        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        True if the candidate object is a duration instance, and its fields are equivalent to that of the instance on which the method is invoked. Else False.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()

        Returns a short textual representation of the instance. This method returns category to which the instance relates, in addition to the information that is returned by toStringTimeOnly().

        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A string representation of the instance, summarising the duration in terms of days, hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds; as well as providing the category to which this instance relates.

      • toStringFull

        public java.lang.String toStringFull()

        Returns a full textual representation of the instance.

        Returns:
        A string representation of the instance, summarising the duration in terms of days, hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds; but also providing details of the method, thread and class to which it relates.

      • toStringTimeOnly

        public java.lang.String toStringTimeOnly()

        Returns a textual representation of the 'time only' portion of this instance. Thus, this method provides no information on the requirement or category that the instance relates to.

        Returns:
        A string representation of the instance, which only summarises the duration in terms of days, hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
